title: 114_hr2950
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Contracting Clarity Act of 2015". It includes findings and the sense of Congress. Native Hawaiians are economically disadvantaged, with lower educational attainment, higher unemployment rates, and underrepresentation in certain occupations compared to national averages. In 2001, the Department of the Treasury found that Native Hawaiian households faced economic challenges, with lower average earnings ($70,686) compared to the national average ($74,657), higher reliance on food assistance programs (18.8% vs. 13.4%), higher poverty rates (13.2% vs. 11.7%), and lower savings account ownership (34% vs. 29.5%). In 2001, the Department of the Treasury identified barriers to capital access and financial services for Native Hawaiians on Hawaiian Home Lands. Policies supporting economic equality for Native Hawaiians benefit the entire United States. Participation in the free enterprise system is crucial for their economic self-sufficiency. Government procurement from Native Hawaiian Organizations provides opportunities for them to contribute to the economy. Consistent promotion and Federal assistance for Native Hawaiian Organizations will ensure economic equality for Native Hawaiians, providing goods, services, revenue, and jobs. Congress recognizes the importance of supporting these organizations for the benefit of the United States. SEC. 3. SMALL BUSINESS CONFORMITY. HUBZone Eligibility criteria under the Small Business Act are amended to include small business concerns owned by Native Hawaiian Organizations. The Small Business Act is amended to include Native Hawaiian Organizations as economically disadvantaged for the 8(a) Program. The Small Business Act is amended to include Native Hawaiian Organizations as economically disadvantaged for the 8(a) Program, with the amendment taking effect on the date of enactment of the Act.
